page.title: 17EARNLEY MILL
page.content: { Earnley Mill}is an octagonal,black tarred,weather boarded smock mill. They were called smock mills because they looked like a farmer in a smock. It's present owners,Mr.and Mrs.Darby, have traced its history back to 1813. In 1827 it was made higher by giving it a brick base and further strengthened in 1913 and 1933.When working it had four sails and a six bladed fantail.It was the last working mill in Sussex,stopping work in 1946. The mill worked only two pairs of stones,but in 1870 a third pair was added.The Stevens family owned the mill for many years.They ground the local corn and there was a bakery next to the mill.The mill was sold in 1946 and was used as tea rooms until the present owners bought it in 1958.Today used as a home,the mill has no sails.
